description: Greatest k such that binomial(k,n) has fewer than n distinct prime factors.
comments: Table 2 in Selmer's paper has a typo for n = 76. Selmer "cheats" to find a(n) for n>27. - _T. D. Noe_, Apr 05 2007
references: Selmer, Ernst S.; On the number of prime divisors of a binomial coefficient. Math. Scand. 39 (1976), no. 2, 271-281.
N. J. A. Sloane and Simon Plouffe, The Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences, Academic Press, 1995 (includes this sequence).
links: T. D. Noe, Table of n, a(n) for n=1..500
Selmer, Ernst S.; On the number of prime divisors of a binomial coefficient. Math. Scand. 39 (1976), no. 2, 271-281.
mathematica: Join[{1}, Table[n=k; b=1; n0=Infinity; While[n++; b=b*n/(n-k); If[Length[FactorInteger[b]]<k, n0=n]; n<10*n0]; n0, {k,2,30}]] - _T. D. Noe_, Apr 05 2007
author: _N. J. A. Sloane_.
extensions: More terms from Pab Ter (pabrlos(AT)yahoo.com), May 26 2004
